Award.AwardTitle: Von Neumann algebras, subfactors, topology and quantum physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Given a subfactor N of finite index of a factor M, the standard invariant is the direct sum for n from 0 to infinity of the zeroth cohomology of the nth. tensor power of M over N, viewed as an N-N-bimodule. This graded vector space has a lot of structure, in particular that of a ring coming from the simple tensor product. This bears a striking resemblance to the "canonical ring" of algebraic geometry.
Indeed it has been shown that the completion of this canonical ring gives a canonical subfactor whose standard invariant is the same as the original one! This structure will be explored in all its detail, especially the planar algbra structure on the standard invariant which is used to describe and analyse the canonical ring. Various combinatorial structures such as Hadamard matrices and Latin squares give rise to these canonical rings but there are serious problems of computational complexity. The large n limit of random nxn matrices also gives such structures. Technically the tensor product over N referred to above is the Connes tensor product and we are looking at how this tensor product may be directly relevant to quantum physics.

Fock space is the mathematical engine of second quantization, a process that, among other things, is necessary to make quantum mechanics compatible with special relativity. There are fermionic and bosonic versions. In our research we are pursuing a more general Fock space based on a subalgebra and an algebra.
The small algebra corresponds to the scalars in second quantization and the large one corresponds to the first quantized Hilbert space.
One can no longer freely exchange particles as in the fermionic and bosonic situations. But annihilation and creation operators still exist and form a ring analogous to the canonical ring of a projective variety. In our situation the canonical ring/Fock space has much more structure, namely that of a planar algebra. Roughly speaking this gives operations for every map.
Imagine the map of a country like the United States. Upon putting an element of the Fock space into each State on the map one would get an output for the whole country, which is another element of the Fock space. To say that our structure is a planar algebra means that such an operation on Fock space exists for every conceivable map that can be drawn on a piece of paper.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Subfactors are mathematical structures that arise in the quantum world when Einstein causality is taken into account. Observables localised in a space-time region form a so-called "factor" and those observables necessarily commute with ones localised in another region which cannot be reached without exceeding the speed of light. To any subfactor is associated an "index" which is a number bigger than one. Subfactors of index less than or equal to four were completely understood by the 1990's and by 2000 all these small index subfactors were known to occur in quantum field theory in two dimensions. 

But in the mid 1990's Haagerup discovered two remarkable subfactors of index between 4 and 5. The first is now known as "the Haagerup" and has index approximately equal to 4.3027756. The Haagerup is a remarkable instance of mathematical symmetry of a new kind. A large part of the work supported by this NSF grant involved better understanding the Haagerup and a systematic attempt to understand its context by pushing the classification of subfactors by index as far as possible beyond 4. It was discovered with the help of considerable computer work, verified on different platforms,  that there are exactly 10 subfactors of index between 4 and 5  of these a total of 4 are known to arise in quantum field theory. The appearance in quantum field theory of the other 6, and especially the Haagerup itself as the simplest of the 6, remains a challenging open question. The subfactors come in pairs of two, each sharing the same index so there are exactly 5 index values of subfactors between 4 and 5. (Many people were involved in this project and supported by this grant directly and indirectly.) At index 5 there are exactly 10 more subfactors but they all arise from transitive permutation groups on 5 letters and thus can be seen in quantum field theory by known constructions.

Our approach to understanding the Haagerup and its cousins has been to use the planar algebra ideas developed by the PI in the 1990's and 2000's. Algebraic and diagrammatic relations similar to those used in the theory of knots are seen to govern the structure of a subfactor. This approach to subfactors is known as "skein theory" in hommage to John Conway who introduced it in knot theory. A skein theoretic construction of the Haagerup along was given by Emliy Peters in her thesis and her ideas were greatly deepened and sharpened herself, together with Bigelow, Morrison and Snyder to achieve the construction of the "extended Haagerup" which is by far the most difficult of the 10 subfactors of index between 4 and 5. 

Skein theoretic methods were  also used to show that no other than 5 index values are alllowed between 4 and 5. A veritable hodgepodge of other methods, including some nineteenth century results on cyclotomic integers, were used as well. This classification project is ongoing.

Index is but one way to measure the complexity of a subfactor. The planar algebra perspective gives another-the number of skein-theoretic generators and relations required to define it. The construction of subfactors by skein theoretic complexity has been another major topic of research funded by this grant.
